quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 2 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 2.7: Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Mixtures
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Types of mixtures and their properties

questions.question: Which term describes a mixture that is uniform in composition throughout?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous mixtures have the same proportions of components throughout any given sample.

questions.question: Which of the following is a classic example of a heterogeneous mixture?
questions.explanation: Italian dressing contains distinct layers of oil, vinegar, and herbs that can be seen and separated easily.

questions.question: Another name for a homogeneous mixture is a:
questions.explanation: Solutions are homogeneous mixtures where one substance is completely dissolved in another.

questions.question: If you take two different samples from a heterogeneous mixture, what will you likely find?
options: The samples have different ratios of components.
The samples are identical in every way.
The samples have turned into pure elements.
The samples have lost all their mass.
questions.explanation: Because heterogeneous mixtures are not uniform, the composition varies from one part of the mixture to another.

questions.question: An alloy, such as brass or bronze, is classified as a:
questions.explanation: Alloys are solid solutions where metals are mixed uniformly at the atomic level.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a 'Suspension'?
options: A heterogeneous mixture where large particles settle out over time.
A homogeneous mixture that never settles.
A pure substance made of two metals.
A gas dissolved in a liquid.
questions.explanation: Suspensions, like muddy water, are heterogeneous because the particles are large enough to be seen and will eventually sink to the bottom.

questions.question: Which of these is a homogeneous mixture of gases?
options: The air in a typical room
questions.explanation: Clean air is a solution of nitrogen, oxygen, and other gases that is uniform throughout.

questions.question: A 'Colloid' is a mixture that has properties between a solution and a suspension. Which is an example?
questions.explanation: Milk is a colloid because its particles are larger than those in a solution but small enough that they don't settle out.

questions.question: What happens to the individual properties of substances when they form a mixture?
options: The substances retain their original properties.
The substances lose all their physical properties.
The substances gain entirely new chemical formulas.
questions.explanation: In any mixture, whether homo- or heterogeneous, the components are physically combined and keep their own identities.

questions.question: The Tyndall Effect (scattering of light) can be used to distinguish a solution from a colloid. Which one scatters light?
questions.explanation: The larger particles in a colloid or suspension scatter light, making the beam visible, whereas a true solution does not.
